questions.text: Thanks for doing the dishes.
Let’s focus on refining your presentation skills step by step.
You need to listen better in meetings.
Don't let this setback discourage you—you’re doing great!
Your progress on the project exceeded the expected timeline.
That report was outstanding, fantastic job!
You really struggle to handle conflict effectively.
When you interrupt our meetings, it creates confusion and slows progress.
You asked two questions and answered them yourself before anyone else had a chance to answer.
questions.evilNote: This is an observation that could be used as a starting point for feedback, but on its own it doesn't provide any guidance or judgment. It could be perceived as passive-aggressive or as a veiled criticism without offering any constructive advice.

questions.text: If I were you, I’d start preparing the slides at least a week in advance to avoid the last-minute rush.
You might want to consider using a password manager to keep your credentials secure.
I suggest you BCC the manager on these types of emails just to keep them in the loop.
Have you thought about blocking out your calendar for deep work? It really helped me focus.
Thank you for jumping in to help with the client call today; your expertise really saved the deal.
I really appreciate you taking the time to explain the codebase to the new interns.
Thanks for keeping the kitchen clean this week; it makes a huge difference for everyone.
I’m grateful for your patience while I was navigating that difficult personal situation.
Next time, let's look at how you can structure the opening of your pitch to grab attention faster.
I’d like to work with you on refining your delegation skills so you can focus more on strategy.
Think about how you could have handled that objection differently to keep the conversation open.
Let’s pair up on the next module so I can show you some shortcuts in the new framework.
Your report was disorganized and contained several factual errors that we had to fix.
Your lack of contribution during the brainstorming session was quite noticeable.
You’ve got this! The progress you've made over the last month has been incredible.
Don't let this setback discourage you; I've seen what you're capable of when you're at your best.
Keep going—you are so close to cracking the solution to this bug.
I believe in your ability to lead this project, even if it feels a bit overwhelming right now.
Based on our metrics, you met all your KPIs for the quarter with a 10% margin.
Your performance on the last project was slightly below the expected standard for your seniority.
You’ve consistently delivered high-quality work that aligns perfectly with our brand guidelines.
In comparison to the rest of the team, your output volume is currently in the top tier.
Fantastic job on that presentation! You really knocked it out of the park.
You are such a natural leader; the way you handled that conflict was brilliant.
That was an incredibly elegant solution to a very messy problem.
You have a real gift for making complex topics sound simple.
When you interrupt me in front of clients, I feel undermined and it makes me lose my confidence.
I felt really supported when you spoke up for my idea after everyone else dismissed it.
It makes me feel anxious when you change the project deadlines without discussing it with me first.
I really enjoy collaborating with you because your energy makes the work feel less like a chore.
I think you should come into the office earlier.
You never seem to be ready when the meeting starts, and it’s disrespectful to everyone's time.
questions.evilNote: This uses shaming language ('disrespectful') rather than focusing on the impact of the behavior.

questions.text: Your deep-seated fear of rejection is preventing you from taking the risks necessary for growth.
questions.evilNote: Armchair psychology. Assigning deep-seated psychological motives to a peer is often a form of boundary-crossing or bullying.

questions.text: You seem to have an avoidant personality when it comes to dealing with direct conflict.
questions.evilNote: Labeling a colleague with a 'personality type' to explain away their behavior is reductive and unprofessional.

questions.text: I think your subconscious bias against the marketing team is clouding your judgment.
questions.evilNote: This is a 'masked' criticism that attacks the person's character and subconscious rather than their specific actions.

questions.text: Your need for constant external validation is starting to affect the team's velocity.
questions.evilNote: Pathologizing a teammate's work style ('need for validation') is a high-conflict feedback tactic.

questions.text: The tone of your last email was overly aggressive and unprofessional.
questions.evilNote: Using subjective, loaded labels like 'aggressive' without providing specific examples can feel like an attack rather than constructive help.

questions.text: Your need to fit in is preventing you from generating good results.
questions.evilNote: This focuses on a perceived character flaw rather than objective performance metrics.
